blocks.text: In security work, you’re defending against many different risks: attackers trying to gain access, accidents that cause outages, and physical threats to buildings and equipment. A security control is any safeguard you use to reduce risk—by preventing an event, detecting it, or correcting its impact.

Security+ commonly classifies controls in two ways. First, by category: technical control, managerial control (also called administrative control), operational control, and physical control. Second, by type: preventive control, deterrent control, detective control, corrective control, compensating control, and directive control.

items: Category = how it’s implemented (technology, management direction, people/process, or physical means).
Type = what it’s intended to do (prevent, deter, detect, correct/restore, compensate, or direct).
Real-world controls can sometimes fit multiple boxes depending on implementation.
